Best bagels in town. They recently have taken the way of the economy and shrunk a bit but still the best! Awesome cream cheese too. This was the first place to bring authentic pastrami to town as well. Oh so good.

When it comes to crispy-outside doughy-inside hand-rolled bagely goodness this place is the real deal. They offer a variety of specials (this weekend they had soft shell crab and sword fish options for their bagel sandwiches, wiggity whaaaat?) and pile the cream cheese to the sky. Oh, and the cream cheese! They offer exotic (well, as exotic as cream cheese gets) flavors like walnut raisin, chimichurri, and olive, plus three tofu flavors. The bagels and sandwiches are super affordable- definitely worth stopping in on your way to work or while perusing the farmer's market on Saturday.

Visited Gotham Bagels for the first time this weekend. I immediately liked the New York-deli vibe and the variety of menu choices, which offered everything from bagel sandwiches to vegan cream cheese and prepared deli foods. I ordered the everything bagel with scallion cream cheese, topped with avocado and a fried egg. The flavors went really well together, and the cream cheese was delicious.  In terms of the actual bagel itself, I wasn't too impressed with the quality/texture-as someone who has had real New York bagels a lot, I went in knowing that these weren't going to be as good-still, bagel was a little hard, and the texture was mildly chewy which I wasn't a fan of. The sandwich was good, and for a local bagel place in Madison that has a cute vibe, I'd go back.

Flies everywhere....Gross... The bagels themselves aren't bad, but not fantastic either and you get enough cream cheese for 2 bagels on the one you order too. While I haven't gotten sick or had terrible service like some of the other people, the whole experience of eating while flies circled my head was enough to make me never return.

It was a random accident.  I wasn't quite up for the commitment of a full brunch and the obligatory bill, but I needed to find a place that would have something small enough to take the edge off.  High gluten has been off my radar for a while, due to blood sugar issues that I try hard to keep in control.  They have soup here, and how much risk is there with that selection?  As it turns out, more than I thought.  No cup available (or even offered when inquired) forced me to pony up $5 for a bowl of one of the more tepid and oversalted soups I've encountered in recent memory.  The FOH register guy who may have had some kind of mood disorder took my soup to the prep area, where I waited about 10 minutes for what should have been a 1 minute nuke job in the microwave.  The cast of characters working there would have been at home as extras in a revamped Mad Max movie, but I digress.  Let's just say when I am walking on that block, I won't be stopping back for a while.
Food is good, but it's always shocking how, with less than 5 people in the shop, it can take 20 minutes or more to get your toasted bagel. Come with a book and not an appetite.

My life partner thoroughly enjoys the lox and I loved their strawberry cream cheese, unfortunately they discontinued it and we haven't gone back since. Their cranberry juice is off the chain, the price eh not so much.   Please bring back the delicious pink delight!

Was slightly disappointed that they were out of everything bagels, but there were plenty of others to choose from. It might have been the best pumpernickel bagel I've had. NY style, not too dense, and a perfect light toast. I had mine with lox and they did not spare on the cream cheese or fish. Awesome sandwich. Next time I'll try the Brighton which is what my friend ordered and looked amazing.   I splurged on a fresh squeezed oj that had just the right amount of pulp and was def worth the $3. My friend was jealous and wished she ordered one too.   In typical Sunday fashion, I also had a tall coffee. I really appreciated the choice between dark and light roast. I only wished they had sleeves for the cups since it was a bit warm on my hand without but great coffee all the same.   Most importantly, the service was excellent. We were greeted right away and the staff were friendly, conversational, and quick service.   Great experience with delicious food. Can't wait to go back

Spent some of my best years in Manhattan, so you bet your sweet ass I was excited to finally try the bagels here. Looking for that sweet cultural sanctuary in this vanilla little town.  Welp, I ordered an untoasted plain bagel with vegetable cream cheese.   I'm not a fan of warm cream cheese nor am I fan of toasted bagels. Frankly, I shouldn't have to explain why I would like to have my almost $4 bagel this way, as I am the paying guest.  My bagel came toasted. My cream cheese was warm.   Granted, I did not complain for 2 reasons, 1 I was starving, 2 the staff didn't seem like they would be receptive to me asking for another bagel.   Perhaps, unlike many of the people who live in Madison, the owners assume none of "us" have been to New York. New York isn't like in Seinfeld - no soup nazi. Local business owners in NY know how to keep their customers because they are aware there are 15 other locations people can choose from. By the way, you are in the Midwest now; so showing a little bit of niceness won't kill your business or NY schtick. Because I guarantee, the very pale and corn fed cashier isn't a transplant from the Bronx. She knows how to say thank you, but for some reason she doesn't feel it necessary to say so in this establishment.   Will not be returning.

I went back to Gotham craving a bagel, forgetting my past disappointments. I was more disappointed than ever.  The food is just not good. The ham, trying to be fancy, is so disgustingly salty and does not belong on an egg and cheese sandwich. The sausage is also some weird patty and not a normal sausage patty you'd have on a breakfast sandwich.  Gotham says it's a NY style bagel shop but misses the mark when it tries too hard. The bagels are great but your egg sandwiches are almost inedible (my friend and I both picked at ours and didn't finish).   The wait for the food is far too long, it's overpriced and nobody smiles.
Good solid food. Large portions. Nice atmosphere and good price point. This is my go-to place on the square.

Gotham Bagels offers a good, quick, cheap lunch or snack in downtown Madison. The bagels here are fairly high quality and you can mix and match and make interesting bagel sandwiches with a variety of vegetable spreads and also tofutti-based spreads.  I had a "V" sandwich on a toasted garlic bagel ($4.28 with tax) which consisted of arugula, tofutti-scallion spread, tomatoes, avocado, and roasted poblano peppers. It was pretty tasty and quite filling and cheap; however, the sandwich is totally overloaded and quite messy to handle, which forced me to use at least a few napkins (better to eat these sandwiches sitting down at a table, not on-the-go or in the car).  The location in downtown Madison is good, though the place closes too early (3 p.m.). One other suggestion for improvement: add some mockmeat options, such as fakin' bacon and Tofurkey; Gotham's vegan options are good, but don't go far enough.

Visited Madison for just 5 days and came here for bagels in three different occasions. BEST BAGELS EVER! Handrolled, freshly made, DELICIOUS. So many options to choose from. And that pastrami... Oh that pastrami!

Had to get a quick bite and stopped through for breakfast this morning. Had an "Everything" bagel with their special jalapeno garlic cream cheese, not toasted.  It was "everything" I could hope for in a bagel. Not too soft, not too hard - just right, flavorful, easy to eat. The cream cheese was so fluffy and tasty.   I couldn't find caloric information anywhere, but I can't imagine it's any good. This was my "cheat" breakfast of the week.

Here's the rub. I go here often and love the bagels! They are the best in town by far. However, the service is excruciatingly slow and inconsistent . I still go there despite this , just not as often as i would normally. I would move this score to a five if they ever remedied this.

Thanks Gotham, for single-handedly destroying the beautiful Sunday morning.  In a past, I did have complained about the slow service, but never mind about that. Because this morning's unexpected rude awakening by the cashier just ranked #1 on my list of bad food service experience.  I don't know what went wrong, but if I'm paying $25/pound for lox and putting few changes in the tip jar, is it really unreasonable to expect a courtesy service, or at least an average one?  To be fair, during the week day mornings, I do receive nice "good morning" and equally pleasant service. Maybe Sunday is a bad day. Maybe the cashier girl wasn't fully awake, or maybe, I shouldn't bother picking up bagels from them altogether.

I've mentioned before that I'm not in love with New York City like some people are, but I am a fan of certain aspects of the city. And after visiting Gotham bagels, this is one little slice of New York that I am glad has landed in Madison.  The specials announced on the board were all named after the current presidential contenders, but unlike those folks, every single one of the specials sounded amazing. I settled on the Sanders, basically a New York bagel plus whitefish and arugula. It was heavenly. Prepared with precision, plentiful and super fresh ingredients, neatly wrapped and easy to handle presentation, and absolutely delicious flavors. The pickle was the biggest surprise as it was sweet and sour and extremely spicy, enough to make me break a little sweat on this cold winter day. Pow!   The menu is extensive and there were so many that I'll need to come back and try. Colectivo coffee and many other beverages, and a deli case with salads and other premade foods sold by the pound.  The cashier was friendly, but there was a dark, brooding, semi surly guy preparing food which only added to the NYC style authenticity. Four stars because the interior was a little messy around the trash bins, and what is up with the grungy, yellow stained drop ceiling tiles? Was the place a cigar bar in its last life?  PS: 15% off your first Yelp! check-in purchase, not too shabby!
Delicious NYC-style bagel.

Disappointing. It's such a simple concept. Bagels with different spreads, breakfast sandwiches and more gourmet sandwiches.   The bagels themselves are delicious - some of the best I've ever had. But I'm referring to the bagels untoasted with my own cream cheese.   The times I've ordered a bagel with cream cheese or in a breakfast sandwich were surprisingly mediocre. I ordered the bacon egg and cheese sandwich once, and another time a garlic bagel with jalapeño garlic cream cheese.   The sandwich was just alright. The bacon was the star, otherwise the sandwich was overpriced and bland (~$6?)  The bagel toasted with cream cheese was worse. The outside of the bagel was toasted until an almost black brown, but the bagel was cold. The cream cheese could've filled up a tub you'd buy from a grocery store. Cold, hard, and overwhelmed by cold cream cheese - not the most pleasant  So I'd recommend grabbing a bagel with nothing on it, toasting if you'd like, and using your own cream cheese. This way, their bagels are some of the best.

Rachel B identified the bagel, she just didn't know it. These are not NY bagels. Sorry to disappoint you Gotham Bagels, but you are not dense enough to classify yourself as New York. You are more of a Montreal or even a Toronto style bagel, although you are slightly larger than a classic Toronto bagel, like Gryfe's. Yes the name says Gotham, and they have the cute menu that mentions all the clever NYC names, but your bagel is not NY. The bagel is not quite chewy enough, it is not dense enough, the flavor is a little bland. New York bagels are boiled. Montreal bagels contain honey and are baked in a wood fired oven. That is a Montreal Bagel, or a Toronto bagel. You might consider changing your name to Fairmount Bagels, or  St. Viateur bagels. The true New York bagel is dense, chewy and can be eaten completely as it stands, nothing on it, their is a flavor that pops out from the bagel that is undeniably New York. It can not be duplicated, not in Madison, not in Boston, not anywhere. However, it can be made close. Your bagels are too fluffy, too white bread to be a New York bagel. Bagels Forever is a closer NY bagel. Your bagels are good, but your classification is incorrect. Sorry to disappoint Gotham.

Oh Gotham,  The dreadful disposition of every person that works there is enough for me to rate you so poorly, but you know what, cranky staff aside, (I guess this is part of your NY shtick?) it's STILL hard for me to give you anything greater than two stars, as all 3 times I've been there, I've left with a botched up order.  Now shame on me for not checking orders the second and third time, right... but shame on you for hearing whole wheat bagel with egg and sausage and giving me a whole wheat bagel with bacon and cheese. Short of getting back there and making the thing myself... I'm not certain how to have a stellar experience at your place of business.   I could understand if the place was packed. I could understand if you were short staffed and moving quick. I could understand if I was making substitutions to an existing sandwich and the person making my sandwich got confused. I can't understand how when there's no line, 5 visible employees and I choose "Design Your Own" it's so blatantly wrong. And the parking situation isn't conducive to someone driving back there to remedy it, and so for the third time I threw $6 in the trash.  But no more. Perhaps if I hear the operation gets tighter, if someone tells me it's worth another shot, I'll go back? But when I do I'll order a plain bagel that I adorn with fixins I have in my fridge. You've programmed me to believe there's no other way.

Bagels Forever and Gotham are tied for best bagels in Madison IMHO. I've only ever had bagels, cream cheese, and coffee here, so I can't comment on much else. The bagels are pretty close to a real east coast bagel, but they seem too big to me. The cream cheese is good, they make their own and have a lot of flavors. They really layer it on the bagels, so much so that I usually end up taking off ~90% of it before eating.  The service here sucks...the guys who work here are slow, rude, and have trouble remembering your order (which they write down!). The prices are also pretty steep for bagels.  Definitely worth trying especially if you're downtown, but you can get bagels that are just as good (ok yes they're smaller) for cheaper at Bagels Forever!

Unfortunately, despite having a pretty stellar breakfast sandwich and downtown's only edible (and very delicious) bagel, I will no longer be patronizing Gotham Bagels.  Their food is delicious; I've been lucky to have had former employees share some of their delightful deli options with me in the past. The egg and cheddar on pumpernickel with arugula and tomato has been my favorite hangover remedy for a couple of years now. The prices are very fair for their quality and the fact that it is a deli. Those who disagree are encouraged to consider their location and their overhead.  However, their service has gone significantly downhill, and they are severely lacking in good management. This morning I swung by before work with my partner. We each ordered an egg and whatever sandwich, grabbed beverages and sat down to wait. I was so excited when the customer prior to us finally got her sandwich, as it was very busy and I was very hungry. Thirty minutes into our visit we realized employees were doing prep work and we still hadn't received our orders. As I was already going to be late to work, we decided to ask for refunds, at which point the manager (maybe the owner) went to the kitchen and realized the printer was unplugged, and the kitchen hadn't received our orders. I thought for sure the young lady who took our orders had seen us sitting sandwichless for much too long after the cook had finished prior orders. The man gave us our requested refund, but I'm upset that my tip money sat in that jar after I had left.  One experience is something, but this was the THIRD time in half a year this happened to me. Three strikes, I'm done. I make the best breakfast sandwich in town anyway.  As the manager of a retail brick-and-mortar , I am quite disappointed to see a lack of the same care and diligence I put into my store. They really need to put more effort into organization and accountability.  But damn, I'm gonna miss those bagels.

Hands down the best bagels in Madison. Their bagel breakfast sandwiches are made with real, fresh ingredients, putting Einsteins to shame. You'll really taste the difference.  We liked the food, service, atmosphere, value, bagels, super tasty food, real italian sausage patties, fresh eggs, food served in charming wicker baskets, smooth espresso, quality wood furnishing, seeing bagels being made, the nice clean space and filling food.  We disliked that there were no chairs - only stools, no posted menu, no specific food pickup location, and that the staff was not prepared for unusual requests and obviously were not native English speakers.

The bagel with the salmon! Very good, very filling and doesn't make you feel bad about eating out since they do have have tasty, healthy options! Went in here for a quick lunch, and I do advise against that! Usually there is a line and decent wait. But trust me, if you have the time, it's worth the wait! Every time I've been here I've had a great meal. Thanks

Great place near the square to stop in for a quick bagel. Haven't tried any other local bagel places in Madison yet, but this one is pretty good. My roommate assured me that it's as authentic NYC as you can get (outside of NYC, that is).  I've had the sesame bagel with salmon and lox, which was outstanding! I've also ordered the everything bagel, which to me is very, very salty. I like that they use sea salt, but come on! I had to pick some of it off, which in turn removed the "everything" from the bagel. I've had this with the salmon cream cheese, which is a nice alternative to the salmon and lox (and less expensive).   They seem to have a lot of ingredients for sandwiches and such. Will definitely return to try some of their other options.

Gotham Bagels is the spot to be on a Sunday morning. My girlfriend lives a few blocks from here and we do not miss a Gotham run on the weekend.  The bagels are dope. Excellent consistency, great size and all your classic varieties. My personal favorite is their Super Egg Everything, which is an egg bagel topped with, you guessed it, everything. If you're really about that life, check out the bialy.  The cream cheese selection is also on point, although I rarely venture away from chive because I just really like chive.  They have new special sandwiches every week that are typically adventurous and fantastic. This past weekend I had the "Los Angeles," which had spicy chorizo, cheese and salsa verde. 'Twas delish.

I might have given this place a better review if the owner hadn't yelled "Hey! I'm trying to run a business here!" at me for having the audacity to not hear him call my name the first time in a loud and crowded restaurant. I also might have given this place a better review if 10 minuets later the owner hadn't accused my girlfriend of stealing a bottle of water, which she didn't of course. However, I might not have, because the food wasn't that special anyway. Maybe keep the NYC-style bagels, and lose the NYC-style attitude?

I has another enjoyable experience at Gotham today, this time for lunch instead of breakfast. I really enjoy their bagels and cream cheese schmears, but today I was really feeling like a sandwich. I decided to try one of their specials: kofte with cucumber, tomato, and yogurt sauce. They also had a really good looking soup of the day so I gave that a shot as well.   The soup was Italian sausage with potato and kale, and it was awesome! There were a lot of different flavors working here; fattiness and spice from the sausage, bitterness from the kale, richness from the potato. Really, really good stuff! The soup was filling without being heavy and ended up being a great compliment for the sandwich i ordered.   I asked for the kofte special on a garlic bagel and it was a really solid choice! The kofte was grilled up hot and fresh and was very juicy and flavorful. While it was being made I was asked if I wanted onions (which were not on the menu description), to which I replied 'of course'. The onions were a great addition, but unfortunately I didn't get any tomato on the sandwich. The yogurt sauce was a really nice counterpoint to the kofte and the cucumbers were crisp and added a nice brightness.   Best of all, on a Tuesday afternoon I had the chance to sit and enjoy Gotham Bagels without a crazy line and huge crowd. There were a few other lucky folks around so it wasn't dead, but not jammed like a weekend morning during farmer's market season.   For my money Gotham's bagels are among the best in the area and I look forward to enjoying them again soon and often.

Yummy! After a big weekend of drinking in Madison, we came to Gotham to grab some breakfast before heading on the road.  The place reminds me of a bagel shop ones might find in New York.  The line was okay, but it was still pretty early, about 9am.  We got the everything bagels with bacon, egg, and cheese as well as a tuna salad and egg salad to go for lunch.  It did take a while for them to make but it did not disappoint.  After being there for about 30 minutes, the line managed to get very long, pretty much out the door, so I guess we got there at the perfect time before the huge rush!

This spot is the quintessential bagel experience in Madison.  The bagels are fresh, hand rolled delights.  There are bagel sandwich options, as well as, toasted bagel and cream cheese.  If you like bagels, there is something here for you.    My go to bagel is the plain because it doesnt need anything else.  I usually pair it with the plain cream cheese.  But lately, I have been really into the smoked salmon cream cheese.  Bagel, cream cheese, and a large coffee cost six dollars.  Sat mornings are busy but the line moves well.  If you want to sit in, just watch for an opening or share a communal table.  But if it's warm enough outside just take it to go.  The Capitol Lawn is just a block away.

I am happy to have finally tried Gotham! as a new yorker, bagels and deli's are soemthing i STILL miss. I will say this first- bagels are good.. they are NOT as good as NY bagels but closer than anything else in the Madison area. There sammiches are GREAT tho- and I swear I never, ever thought I would get a yummy chicken cutlet sammich unless I was in the Northeast,(mst people don't even know what a chicken cutlet is here!!) and Gotham proved me wrong! Great sammiches, so worth it... I wish we could do half stars.. this is a 3.5 for sure!!

Coming from the New York area, I'm very snobby about my bagels. This place is by far the best bagel joint in Madison. I would even say it's the only place I have found outside of the NY area that serves real bagels.  When comparing these to other bagels in the Midwest, it's a blowout. Other places don't even compare.  When comparing these to the best bagels I've had back home, these hold their own, which is saying a lot. I wouldn't say these are among the greatest bagels I've ever had, but if I had them in NYC, I would classify them as good, which is quite a feat.  Bagel selection and spread selection is great. Breakfast sandwiches are great. Lox is great. It's nice to have a little bit of New York available in Madison (considering the lack of pizza in the area).

I went to the Farmers Market to walk around in the glorious warm sun and left with pretty much just carbs...I bought bread, pasta and unfortunately, bagels from Gotham.  The bagels themselves weren't bad...nothing to write home about in my opinion..but not awful.  It was the service that is really why I would never go back.  I waited in line with a friend-she ordered her bagels and then I went to order next and was VERY loudly accused of cutting in line by a rude man who seemed to think he was in charge.  I calmly explained that I was waiting here the entire time and then started to order the bagels but he was extremely short and rude with me the entire time.  No time for that-I'll get my bagels from Bagels Forever instead!

Okay, their bagels are good. The stuff they put on the bagels is good. HOWEVER - they are overpriced. There is almost always a huge line, which moves slowly. Even when it is crazy busy on the weekend, there is usually only one person on the grill and so the food takes forever. Expect to be treated rudely by someone, at some point.   My fiance refuses to go here anymore #solidarity

My first visit to Gotham didn't quite blow me away like I thought it was going to, sadly. However, I may not have ordered one of the most popular items, so I think I'll give it another shot sometime to change my opinion!  My roommates and I all went for the spicy Italian sausage, cheddar and egg sandwich on Gotham's everything bagel. They came out pretty quickly (we were there around 9 on a Sunday morning -- it wasn't too busy) and were neatly made. I noticed right away that the size of the bagel maybe seemed a bit small? But that could have been the normal for all of Gotham's bagels -- I'm not sure. Anyways, like I said, I wasn't blown away by my breakfast, but I will say that the italian sausage was super yummy -- the cashier informed me that it's all made in house. And I'm a sucker for some egg yolkiness in my food. Next time, I might try some of their lox!  I think I would have changed out the type of bagel, in hindsight. The bagel was so thick, I wished that I had the sandwich on something thinner. Also, due to the bagel being toasted and thick, I ended up scraping the roof of my mouth on the tougher part of the bagel, which was really annoying/painful for the rest of the day and the day after whenever I ate something. I know that Gotham makes bialys which are (I googled this) Polish in origin and are baked rolls, similar to bagels. They seem to be a bit thinner, so I think I'd go for that next time.  Overall, I think I would have been much happier with a different bagel choice -- so I'm excited to give Gotham another try!

They have some good bagels in town. Good selection of cream cheeses and tofu spreads. I also liked their idea of serving bagel crisps along with each order ( i hope they make these bagel crisps out of unused bagels at the end of the day to avoid wastage). Sure they have a lot of people hanging around at this place in the mornings, but they can surely improve in providing much quicker and better service.

Long lines go by fast and well worth the wait. Bacon, egg, and cheese on sesame or super egg bagel is the go-to. Perfect compliment to a sunny day walk around the capital. Great detour to a Saturday farmer's market trip!

It had been a couple of years since I visited Gotham, and decided to stop in and get a toasted pumpernickel with cream cheese and lox. Hadn't had one in ages. So here we go, let's take a look. They gave me a nice spicy pickle on top of the wrapped bagel. Nice touch, liked it. Plenty of cream cheese, and the bagel itself didn't disappoint. But hold up.... $6 for this bagel, cream cheese and lox?? And.... hello??? There's not even any red onion or tomato included. I'da thought that was a given when asking for bagel and lox???? Okay, stlightly miffed and disappointed, but still my favorite place here in town for bagels, although there are other options I have yet to try.
By far the best bagels this far from the Big Apple. Efficient counter service. Delicious!

These are the best bagels in Madison and lucky to have east coast quality bagels in the Midwest.   Yes, there is a long line on the weekends, but it moves (I won't say quickly) and is the best grab-and-go brunch.   If you come here near closing you can buy a dozen bagels for practically nothing.

Great bagels and accouterments. I would definitely come here again if I'm ever in Madison. Service is no-frills but I wouldn't call it unfriendly. The menu of bagels and sandwiches is pretty extensive, with specials on the board. There's also a deli case with items like specialty cream cheese and tuna and egg salads on display.  I thought about getting a bagel with smoked whitefish salad since you don't see that everywhere. But in the end I couldn't resist getting a classic bagel with lox. I got mine on an everything bagel with scallion cream cheese and tomato. It was delicious. The bagel was fresh and chewy. The lox and cream cheese were perfectly balanced. It was a little messy to eat but I'm a messy eater to begin with. The coffee is from Colectivo.  I did have a little trouble finding the place. The Google Maps directions were atrocious. Though that's more of a complaint about Google Maps than the restaurant. I tried to come in through the wrong door and I felt a little stupid, but then I saw someone else do the same thing, so maybe it's not just me.

It makes me sad to write this review because I used to love Gotham, but that ship seems to have sailed. Just now, I pulled on their doors to get a bagel at about 140pm on a Wednesday and the door was locked. No sign, no nothing and the guy at the counter just stared at me.   Rewind to about 2 months ago. Again, I went in after the lunch rush (because that is when my scheduled lunch is) to get a bagel. There were 3-4 other customers and probably 4-5 people working. The owner was counting money out of the drawer. He ignored me for a few seconds, glanced up, and then said, She'll help you and gestured toward the girl behind him. She looked surprised but jumped to help me. As I waited for my sandwich, I noticed how dirty everything was. I'm sure they had been busy but it was dead by this point. Finally, I go to the women's bathroom and after using it, find out that the toilet is broken. No sign, no nothing.   Are their bagels/sandwiches/everything delicious? Hell yes. I'm just starting to wonder if it's worth it. The owner should stop counting money and tighten up his biz a little.
Love the food here. Sometimes the owner can be a bit crabby but usually only if they're busy.

My son and I come here before we head over to the Children's Museum in the morning.   I like that they have a lot of different choices of bagel sandwiches or you can get bagels with all sorts of different cream cheeses including a vegan tofu cream cheese which actually tastes really good. I like their lox and cream cheese on a toasted garlic bagel. My son likes the cinnamon raisin bagel.   It can get busy here and you can wait in a line for a while but its good if your willing to wait.

My girlfriend and I went down to the square on Saturday morning and were going to try the brunch at Marigold's Kitchen.  I'm glad that we stumbled across Gotham Bagels instead because it led to a fantastic breakfast and a good overall experience.  The main reason for stepping into the store was because I needed change for the parking meter, and because we couldn't find Marigold's.  The woman behind the counter at Gotham was incredibly pleasant, she had a real down to earth personality and not only did she give me change but she also drew a map on paper of how to get to Marigold's.  This was pretty shocking to me as I was essentially leaving their restaurant for the competition.  Well after that gesture, my girlfriend and I looked around and realized that Gotham actually looked fairly good themselves, so we decided to stay and eat.  They had a full deli section of potato salads and other items, and a menu of dozens of different bagel sandwiches.  The furniture was of a nice rustic wooden decor, and there was a TV with the basketball game on at a very appropriate volume.    While we waited for our food, the nice counter lady brought over a cinnamon roll for us (on the house).  It was delicious, and I'm not even a big fan of that type of pastry.  10 minutes later we got our food, two salivating bagel sandwiches with fresh on-the-spot ingredients and uniquely flavored cheeses, sausages, etc (in the sandwich).  Overall we had a great time and will for sure be coming back again.  It doesn't look like the place you'd get your daily breakfast from, but it's perfect for a nice Saturday or Sunday leisurely trip.

Best bagels in Madison. Bagels are delicious, all the cream cheeses are good and they're always rotating a few specialty ones. I love the Chimichurri cream cheese. Favorite sandwich and go to is the Brighton Beach on Super Egg Everything. They often have very good special sandwiches.   Today I had a cup of the clam and oyster chowder. Wow...tons of clam and oyster meat, so it made for a delicious, perfectly salted, meaty chowder. Also went with my go-to - Brighton Beach.

Here to add to and endorse the reviews of others before me.  I think Gotham has great bagels - real, authentic NY/Philly bagels in every way - always fresh and tasty. Very good sandwiches, chicken salad, and atmosphere as well.  But they lose two big stars for their below standard service. They inexplicably have one slow, indifferent person taking orders, with a handful of other people filling them. What would make more sense and is done at most other delis is that each attendant interact with the customer, take their order, and shepherd it to completion. The wait in line is almost always longer than it needs to be. If the person in front of me has a long, complicated order, it shouldn't matter.   Second, the attendants are often rude and/or indifferent, and it's not just a one-off observation.  The only reason I could see for the owners to tolerate the current situation is that they just do not care about making money.

The people running the register are so extremely rude.  Service is terribly slow, and you constantly see people behind you getting served before you.  My girlfriend got an egg bagel and I ordered a normal bagel and cream cheese.  Surprisingly, her's was done before mine was, and I realize after the fact that I saw it sitting there ready to serve for five or ten minutes before anyone put cream cheese on my bagel to complete our order.  They were also extremely rude to my friend and when he tried to use his debit card (on a $5 order) the guy asked him if he had cash instead.  Who does that?  He eventually accepted the card so obviously it wasn't against policy or anything.  Never again will I go there.

If your reading this review of a Midwest bagel shop and thinking to yourself "Midwest?  Bagels?  Pshaw!", stop right now and throw your monitor/MacBook out the nearest window.  With those naysayers gone, let me continue.  I've been to Manhattan and I've had the bagels, and yes, they're pretty good. Down on Mifflin street, I've had something that tasted just as good minus the NYC stink of man urine.  Good bagels.  Good meat.  Good coffee.   All for under $5.  Naysayers can suck it.

Waited 45min for just 1 1/2 dozen bagels and cream cheese. No sandwiches. Joe (the dude who struts around the place) walked by me (after I had patiently waited 25min) told me I "don't look very patient". I explained to him my order, but "Mr. Customer Service" just made a face and blew me off. Then after 35min I ask the poor guy frantically making sandwiches why I had to wait so long for just bagels, he found out THEY LOST MY ORDER" OMG.  After 45minutes I finally get my $38 worth of bagels and cream cheese in 2 ripping bags. So frustrating. No bagel is good enough for that kind of treatment.

The wife and I happened upon Gotham Bagels our first day in Madison, and we've made it a tradition to go every Saturday. The bagels are amazing and I'm assuming "authentic", but who cares, they're really good.  Part of the assumed authenticity comes from the brusque and curt way the staff deals with customers; it's just like being in New York!!!  Generally they're nice enough and, if nothing else, you get a friggin' amazing bagel out of the interaction. How anyone rates this less than 4-stars is beyond me...

We were walking to a different breakfast spot but, upon seeing the packed restaurant and the "hot bagels" sign, we really couldn't resist. I really wanted to like this place. Bagels are one of my biggest weaknesses, and this place looked legit, but it really did nothing in the end to earn my favor. For starters, there's the wait time. My husband ordered a bagel sandwich and I just ordered a toasted bagel with butter. It took a solid 20 minutes for us to get our food, and it was clear they made my bagel right away and left it to sit, as it was cold. Even worse, the combination of toasting it and letting it sit left me with what amounted to a solid jaw workout as I tried to chew through each bite. I seriously gave up halfway through. Maybe if I'd gotten, as promised, a "hot bagel" and I could have just added butter, that would have been one thing. But the suuuuper over-toasted, chewy option was lackluster at best. My husband's sandwich looked good, but not $10 good. Maybe $7 or $8 good, but $10?! Also, it seems that they pressed it in the process of preparing it, which left him with a similarly impossibly chewy bagel to chew through. I also tried what appeared to be their show stopper, the coffee cake, but it was so unimpressive I threw half of it away. The coffee was disappointing as well. Finally, each bagel dish is garnished with a bagel chip, which made me really excited, but it also tasted so bad I took two bites and gave up. So maybe this would be worth a future visit if I got a bagel to go and heated it up at home, sans toaster, but as it stands, I really don't understand the super high reviews or the crowds of people jostling for their Saturday morning bagel fix. The best thing I had was the bagel itself, and even that was disappointing, so that should say it all.

I want to be clear that I love the actual food here, but also had one of the worst dining experiences of my life here. The Madison chef's network week event was a complete disaster. I had been looking forward to it for a month. Start to finish we were there for 2 hours, 5 minutes of which we actually had our food.   We waited in line for 15 minutes which is fine. We ordered and were told it would be another 20 for our food. 1 hour and fifteen minutes later we received our sandwiches! But we were served two completely different sandwiches from what we ordered. We took them back because they clearly belonged to another customer that had also chosen their brunch spot poorly, and in the off chance that they hadn't died or left to complete a master's degree, we wanted to make sure they got their food.   We gave them back to the line cook who rolled his eyes, looked at us suspiciously, and double checked that we had the intelligence to know what sandwich we'd ordered, since obviously that's the most likely scenario. He then disappeared with the sandwiches and was never heard from again. We were left with no apology, no update as to if our sandwiches even existed in the physical plane, and most importantly, no sandwiches.   We waited an additional half hour to contemplate our bad life choices before our names were called. We got our sandwiches. They weren't on the right bagels, but they were apparently ours. We ate them. They tasted like food which is about all we could process at that point, and left hungry for lunch since breakfast had long passed us by.

I've lived on the West Coast for many dozen years and love it. There are a few things, though, that Easterners always complain about. The lack of decent bagels and the horrors that are passed off as pizza.  Having moved to Madison I was, therefore, optimistic about the chances of finding a decent bagel. And I have. More than decent. I tried Bagels Forever (OK) but these are real big, chewy NY bagels Yay!!!!  Now where can I find a decent Boston-style anchovy pizza??
